member.name: T:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Session.TraceEventProviderOptions
member.summary: TraceEventProviderOptions represents all the optional arguments that can be passed to EnableProvider command.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Session.TraceEventProviderOptions.#ctor
member.summary: Create new options object with no options set

member.name: M:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Session.TraceEventProviderOptions.#ctor(System.String[])
member.summary: Create new options object with a set of given provider arguments key-value pairs. There must be a even number of strings provided and each pair forms a key-value pair that is passed to the AddArgument() operator.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Session.TraceEventProviderOptions.Arguments
member.summary: Arguments are a set of key-value strings that are passed uninterpreted to the EventSource. These can be accessed from the EventSource's command callback.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Session.TraceEventProviderOptions.AddArgument(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: As a convenience, the 'Arguments' property can be modified by calling AddArgument that adds another Key-Value pair to it. If 'Arguments' is not a IDictionary, it is replaced with an IDictionary with the same key-value pairs before the new pair is added.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Session.TraceEventProviderOptions.RawArguments
member.summary: For EventSources, you pass arguments to the EventSource by using key value pairs (this 'Arguments' property). However other ETW providers may expect arguments using another convention. RawArguments give a way of passing raw bytes to the provider as arguments. This is only meant for compatibility with old providers. Setting this property will cause the 'Arguments' property to be ignored.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Session.TraceEventProviderOptions.StacksEnabled
member.summary: Setting StackEnabled to true will cause all events in the provider to collect stacks when event are fired.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Session.TraceEventProviderOptions.ProcessIDFilter
member.summary: Setting ProcessIDFilter will limit the providers that receive the EnableCommand to those that match on of the given Process IDs.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Session.TraceEventProviderOptions.ProcessNameFilter
member.summary: Setting ProcessNameFilter will limit the providers that receive the EnableCommand to those that match on of the given Process names (a process name is the name of the EXE with a path or extension).

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Session.TraceEventProviderOptions.EventIDsToEnable
member.summary: Setting EventIDs to Enable will enable a particular event of a provider by EventID (in addition to those enabled by keywords).

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Session.TraceEventProviderOptions.EventIDStacksToEnable
member.summary: Setting EventIDs to Enable will enable the collection of stacks for a event of a provider by EventID (Has no effect if StacksEnabled is also set since that enable stacks for all events IDs)

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Session.TraceEventProviderOptions.EventIDsToDisable
member.summary: Setting EventIDsToDisable to Enable will disable the event of a provider by EventID This happens after keywords have been processed, so disabling overrides enabling.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Session.TraceEventProviderOptions.EventIDStacksToDisable
member.summary: Setting EventIDs to Enable will disable the collection of stacks for a event of a provider by EventID Has no effect unless StacksEnabled is also set (since otherwise stack collection is off).

member.name: M:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Session.TraceEventProviderOptions.Clone
member.summary: Make a deep copy of options and return it.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Session.TraceEventProviderOptions.FilteringSupported
member.summary: This return true on OS version beyond 8.1 (windows Version 6.3). It means most of the per-event filtering is supported.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Session.TraceEventSessionOptions
member.summary: TraceEventSessionOptions indicates special handling when creating a TraceEventSession.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Session.TraceEventSessionOptions.Create
member.summary: Create a new session, fail if the session already exists. This is the default.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Session.TraceEventSessionOptions.Attach
member.summary: Attach to an existing session, fail if the session does NOT already exist.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Session.TraceEventSessionOptions.NoRestartOnCreate
member.summary: Normally if you create a session it will stop and restart it if it exists already. Setting this flat will disable the 'stop and restart' behavior. This is useful if only a single monitoring process is intended.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Session.TraceEventProviders
member.summary: TraceEventProviders returns information about providers on the system.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Session.TraceEventProviders.GetProviderGuidByName(System.String)
member.summary: Given the friendly name of a provider (e.g. Microsoft-Windows-DotNETRuntimeStress) return the GUID for the provider. It does this by looking at all the PUBLISHED providers on the system (that is those registered with wevtutuil). EventSources in particular do not register themselves in this way (see GetEventSourceGuidFromName). Names are case insensitive. It also checks to see if the name is an actual GUID and if so returns that. Returns Guid.Empty on failure.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Session.TraceEventProviders.GetEventSourceGuidFromName(System.String)
member.summary: EventSources have a convention for converting its name to a GUID. Use this convention to convert 'name' to a GUID. In this way you can get the provider GUID for a EventSource however it can't check for misspellings. Names are case insensitive.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Session.TraceEventProviders.GetProviderName(System.Guid)
member.summary: Finds the friendly name for 'providerGuid' Returns the Guid as a string if can't be found.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Session.TraceEventProviders.MaybeAnEventSource(System.Guid)
member.summary: Returns true if 'providerGuid' can be an eventSource. If it says true, there is a 1/16 chance it is not. However if it returns false, it is definitely not following EventSource Guid generation conventions.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Session.TraceEventProviders.GetPublishedProviders
member.summary:
Returns the Guid of every event provider that published its manifest on the machine. This is the same list that the 'logman query providers' command will generate. It is pretty long (> 1000 entries)
A event provider publishes a manifest by compiling its manifest into a special binary form and calling the wevtutil utility. Typically EventSource do NOT publish their manifest but most operating system provider do publish their manifest.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Session.TraceEventProviders.GetRegisteredOrEnabledProviders
member.summary:
Returns the GUID of all event provider that either has has register itself in a running process (that is it CAN be enabled) or that a session has enabled (even if no instances of the provider exist in any process).
This is a relatively small list (less than 1000), unlike GetPublishedProviders.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Session.TraceEventProviders.GetRegisteredProvidersInProcess(System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns a list of provider GUIDs that are registered in a process with 'processID'. Useful for discovering what providers are available for enabling for a particular process.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Session.TraceEventProviders.GetProviderKeywords(System.Guid)
member.summary: Returns a description of the keywords a particular provider provides. Only works if the provider has published its manifest to the operating system. Throws an exception if providerGuid is not found

member.name: M:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Session.TraceEventProviders.SessionInfosForProvider(System.Guid,System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns a list of TRACE_ENABLE_INFO structures that tell about each session (what keywords and level they are set to, for the provider associated with 'providerGuid'. If 'processId != 0, then only providers in that process are returned.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Session.ProviderDataItem

member.name: T:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Session.TraceEventProfileSources
M:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Session.TraceEventProfileSources.GetInfo
member.summary: Returns a dictionary of keyed by name of ProfileSourceInfo structures for all the CPU counters available on the machine.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Session.TraceEventProfileSources.Set(System.Int32[],System.Int32[])
member.summary: Sets the Profile Sources (CPU machine counters) that will be used if PMC (Precise Machine Counters) are turned on. Each CPU counter is given a id (the profileSourceID) and has an interval (the number of counts you skip for each event you log). You can get the human name for all the supported CPU counters by calling GetProfileSourceInfo. Then choose the ones you want and configure them here (the first array indicating the CPU counters to enable, and the second array indicating the interval. The second array can be shorter then the first, in which case the existing interval is used (it persists and has a default on boot).

member.name: T:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Session.ProfileSourceInfo
member.summary: Returned by GetProfileSourceInfo, describing the CPU counter (ProfileSource) available on the machine.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Session.ProfileSourceInfo.Name
member.summary: Human readable name of the CPU performance counter (eg BranchInstructions, TotalIssues ...)

member.name: F:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Session.ProfileSourceInfo.ID
member.summary: The ID that can be passed to SetProfileSources

member.name: F:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Session.ProfileSourceInfo.Interval
member.summary: This many events are skipped for each sample that is actually recorded

member.name: F:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Session.ProfileSourceInfo.MinInterval
member.summary: The smallest Interval can be (typically 4K)

member.name: F:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Session.ProfileSourceInfo.MaxInterval
member.summary: The largest Interval can be (typically maxInt).

member.summary: Take a stack trace with the event

member.name: T:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceLog
member.summary:
The data model for an Event trace log (ETL) file is simply a stream of events. More sophisticated analysis typically needs a a richer data model then ETL files can provide, and this is the motivation for the ETLX (Event Trace Log eXtended) file format. In particular any analysis that needs non-sequential access to the events or manipulates stack traces associated with events needs the additional support that the ETLX format provides. See the TraceEventProgrammers guide for more on the capabilities of ETLX.
The TraceLog class is the programmatic representation of an ETLX file. It represents the ETLX file as a whole.
ETLX files are typically created from ETL files using the TraceLog.OpenOrCreate method or more explicitly by the TraceLog.CreateFromEventTraceLogFile.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceLog.CreateFromEventTraceLogFile(System.String,System.String,Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceLogOptions)
member.summary:
Given the path to an ETW trace log file (ETL) file, create an ETLX file for the data.
If etlxFilePath is null the output name is derived from etlFilePath by changing its file extension to .ETLX. The name of the ETLX file that was generated.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceLog.OpenOrConvert(System.String,Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceLogOptions)
member.summary:
Open an ETLX or ETL file as a ETLX file.
This routine assumes that you follow normal conventions of naming ETL files with the .ETL file extension and ETLX files with the .ETLX file extension. It further assumes the ETLX file for a given ETL file should be in a file named the same as the ETL file with the file extension changed.
etlOrEtlxFilePath can be either the name of the ETL or ETLX file. If the ETLX file does not exist or if it older than the corresponding ETL file then the ETLX file is regenerated with the given options. However if an up-to-date ETLX file exists the conversion step is skipped.
Ultimately the ETLX file is opened and the resulting TraceLog instance is returned.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceLog.CreateFromTraceEventSession(Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Session.TraceEventSession)
member.summary:
From a TraceEventSession, create a real time TraceLog Event Source. Like a ETWTraceEventSource a TraceLogEventSource will deliver events in real time. However an TraceLogEventSource has an underlying Tracelog (which you can access with the .Log Property) which lets you get at aggregated information (Processes, threads, images loaded, and perhaps most importantly TraceEvent.CallStack() will work. Thus you can get real time stacks from events).
Note that in order for native stacks to resolve symbolically, you need to have some Kernel events turned on (Image, and Process) and only windows 8 has a session that allows both kernel and user mode events simultaneously. Thus this is most useful on Win 8 systems.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceLog.#ctor(System.String)
member.summary: Opens an existing Extended Trace Event log file (ETLX) file. See also TraceLog.OpenOrCreate.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceLog.Events
member.summary:
All the events in the ETLX file. The returned TraceEvents instance supports IEnumerable so it can be used in foreach statements, but it also supports other methods to further filter the evens before enumerating over them.
Note that the TraceEvent returned from this IEnumerable may only be used for one iteration of the foreach. (it is reused for the next event). If you need more lifetime than that you must call Clone() (see 'Lifetime Constraints' in the programmers guide for more).

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceLog.Processes
member.summary: All the Processes that logged an event in the ETLX file. The returned TraceProcesses instance supports IEnumerable so it can be used in foreach statements, but it also supports other methods to select particular a particular process.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceLog.Threads
member.summary: All the Threads that logged an event in the ETLX file. The returned TraceThreads instance supports IEnumerable so it can be used in foreach statements, but it also supports other methods to select particular thread.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceLog.ModuleFiles
member.summary: All the module files (DLLs) that were loaded by some process in the ETLX file. The returned TraceModuleFiles instance supports IEnumerable so it can be used in foreach statements, but it also supports other methods to select particular module file.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceLog.CallStacks
member.summary: All the call stacks in the ETLX file. Normally you don't enumerate over these, but use you use other methods on TraceCallStacks information about code addresses using CallStackIndexes.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceLog.CodeAddresses
member.summary: All the code addresses in the ETLX file. Normally you don't enumerate over these, but use you use other methods on TraceCodeAddresses information about code addresses using CodeAddressIndexes.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceLog.Stats
member.summary: Summary statistics on the events in the ETX file.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceLog.GetCallStackForEvent(Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.TraceEvent)
member.summary:
If the event has a call stack associated with it, retrieve it. Returns null if there is not call stack associated with the event.
If you are retrieving many call stacks consider using GetCallStackIndexForEvent, as it is more efficient.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceLog.GetCallStackIndexForEvent(Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.TraceEvent)
member.summary: If the event has a call stack associated with it, retrieve CallStackIndex. Returns CallStackIndex.Invalid if there is not call stack associated with the event.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceLog.MaxEventIndex
member.summary: Events are given an Index (ID) that are unique across the whole TraceLog. They are not guaranteed to be sequential, but they are guaranteed to be between 0 and MaxEventIndex. Ids can be used to allow clients to associate additional information with event (with a side lookup table). See TraceEvent.EventIndex and EventIndex for more

member.name: M:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceLog.GetEvent(Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.EventIndex)
member.summary: Given an eventIndex, get the event. This is relatively expensive because we need to create a copy of the event that will not be reused by the TraceLog. Ideally you would not use this API but rather use iterate over event using TraceEvents

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceLog.EventCount
member.summary: The total number of events in the log.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceLog.Size
member.summary: The size of the log file in bytes.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceLog.EventsLost
member.summary: override

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceLog.FilePath
member.summary: The file path for the ETLX file associated with this TraceLog instance.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceLog.MachineName
member.summary: The machine on which the log was collected. Returns empty string if unknown.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceLog.OSName
member.summary: The name of the Operating system. Returns empty string if unknown.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceLog.OSBuild
member.summary: The build number information for the OS. Returns empty string if unknown.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceLog.BootTime
member.summary: The time the machine was booted. Returns DateTime.MinValue if it is unknown.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceLog.UTCOffsetMinutes
member.summary: This is the number of minutes between the local time where the data was collected and UTC time. It is negative if your time zone is WEST of Greenwich. This DOES take Daylights savings time into account but might be a daylight savings time transition happens inside the trace. May be unknown, in which case it returns null.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceLog.HasPdbInfo
member.summary: When an ETL file is 'merged', for every DLL in the trace information is added that allows the symbol information (PDBS) to be identified unambiguously on a symbol server. This property returns true if the ETLX file was created from an ETL file with this added information.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceLog.MemorySizeMeg
member.summary: The size of the main memory (RAM) on the collection machine. Will return 0 if memory size is unknown

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceLog.HasCallStacks
member.summary: Are there any event in trace that has a call stack associated with it.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceLog.SampleProfileInterval
member.summary:
If Kernel CPU sampling events are turned on, CPU samples are taken at regular intervals (by default every MSec).
This property returns the time interval between samples.
If the sampling interval was changed over the course of the trace, this property does not reflect that. It returns the first value it had in the trace.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceLog.CurrentMachineIsCollectionMachine
member.summary:
Returns true if the machine running this code is the same as the machine where the trace data was collected.
If this returns false, the path names references in the trace cannot be inspected (since they are on a different machine).

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceLog.Truncated
member.summary: There is a size limit for ETLX files. Thus it is possible that the data from the original ETL file was truncated. This property returns true if this happened.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceLog.Parsers
member.summary: Returns all the TraceEventParsers associated with this log.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceLog.ToString
member.summary: An XML fragment that gives useful summary information about the trace as a whole.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceLog.#ctor(Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Session.TraceEventSession)
member.summary: Create a new real time session called 'sessionName' and connect a TraceLog to it and return that TraceLog. Functionality of TraceLog that does not depend on either remembering past EVENTS or require future knowledge (e.g. stacks of kernel events), will 'just work'.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceLog.RemoveAllButLastEntries``1(System.Collections.Generic.GrowableArray{``0}@,System.Int32)
member.summary: Removes all but the last 'keepCount' entries in 'growableArray' by sliding them down.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceLog.DispatchClonedEvent(Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.TraceEvent)

member.name: M:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceLog.FlushRealTimeEvents(System.Object)

member.name: M:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceLog.GetCodeAddressIndexAtEvent(System.UInt64,Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.TraceEvent)
member.summary: Given a process's virtual address 'address' and an event which acts as a context (determines which process and what time in that process), return a CodeAddressIndex (which represents a particular location in a particular method in a particular DLL). It is possible that different addresses will go to the same code address for the same address (in different contexts). This is because DLLS where loaded in different places in different processes.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceLog.GetCodeAddressAtEvent(System.UInt64,Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.TraceEvent)
member.summary: If an event has a field of type 'Address' the address can be converted to a symbolic value (a TraceCodeAddress) by calling this function. C

It also creates auxiliary data structures associated with the raw events (eg, processes, threads, modules, address lookup maps... member.summary: Special logic to form MemInfoWSTraceData. We take the single event (which has The working sets for every process in the system, an split them out into N events each of which has the processID for the event set properly, and only has the information for that process. The first 3 processes in the list are -1, -2, and -3 that have special meaning.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceLog.GetIncompleteStackForStackEvent(Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.TraceEvent,System.Int64)
member.summary:
Given just the stack event and the timestamp for the event the stack event is to attach to, find the IncompleteStack for the event. If the event to attach to cannot be this will return null but otherwise it will make an IncompleteStack entry if one does not already exist or it.
As part of allocating an Incomplete stack, it will increment the stack counts for target event.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceLog.EmitStackOnExitFromKernel(Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceLog.IncompleteStack@,Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.CallStackIndex,Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceLog.IncompleteStack)
member.summary: Do the processing necessary to attach the user mode stack 'userModeStack' to any of the stacks in listOfIncompleteKernelStacks. It then clears this list. While doing this processing it will check to see if the target stack 'target' is in that list and it will return true if it was.

member.summary: Do the processing necessary to attach the user mode stack 'userModeStack' to any of the stacks in listOfIncompleteKernelStacks. It then clears this list. While doing this processing it will check to see if the target stack 'target' is in that list and it will return true if it was.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceLog.AllocLookup
member.summary: We need a TraceEventDispatcher in the Enumerators for TraceLog that know how to LOOKUP an event We don't actually dispatch through it. We do mutate the templates (to point a particular data record), but once we are done with it we can reuse this TraceEventDispatcher again an again (it is only concurrent access that is a problem). Thus we have an Allocate and Free pattern to reuse them in the common case of sequential access.

It also has properties for looking up the event and provider names, but this information can only be complete if all the TraceEventParsers needed were associated with the TraceLog instance.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceEvents
member.summary:
A TraceEvents represents a list of TraceEvent instances. It is IEnumerable<TraceEvent> but also has additional useful ways of filtering the list.
Note that the TraceEvent returned from this IEnumerable may only be used for one iteration of the foreach. (it is reused for the next event). If you need more lifetime than that you must call Clone() (see 'Lifetime Constraints' in the programmers guide for more).

member.name: M:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceEvents.ByEventType``1
member.summary: Returns a list of events in the TraceEvents that return a payload of type T. Thus ByEventType < TraceEvent > returns all events.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceEvents.GetSource
member.summary:
Returns a TraceEventDispatcher (a push model object on which you can register callbacks for particular events) that will push all the vents in the TraceEvents.
Note that the TraceEvent returned from this callback may only be used for the duration of the callback. If you need more lifetime than that you must call Clone() (see 'Lifetime Constraints' in the programmers guide for more).

member.name: M:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceEvents.Backwards
member.summary: Returns a new list which is the same as the TraceEvents but the events are delivered from last to first. This allows you to search backwards in the event stream.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceEvents.FilterByTime(System.DateTime,System.DateTime)
member.summary: Filter the events by time. Both starTime and endTime are inclusive.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceEvents.FilterByTime(System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Filter the events by time. StartTimeRelativeMSec and endTimeRelativeMSec are relative to the SessionStartTime and are inclusive.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceEvents.Filter(System.Predicate{Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.TraceEvent})
member.summary: Create new list of Events that has all the events in the current TraceEvents that pass the given predicate.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceEvents.Log
member.summary: Returns the TraceLog associated with the events in the TraceEvents

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceEvents.StartTime
member.summary: Returns a time that is guaranteed to be before the first event in the TraceEvents list. It is returned as DateTime

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceEvents.StartTimeRelativeMSec
member.summary: Returns a time that is guaranteed to be before the first event in the TraceEvents list. It is returned as floating point number of MSec since the start of the TraceLog

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceEvents.EndTime
member.summary: Returns a time that is guaranteed to be after the last event in the TraceEvents list. It is returned as DateTime

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceEvents.EndTimeRelativeMSec
member.summary: Returns a time that is guaranteed to be after the last event in the TraceEvents list. It is returned as floating point number of MSec since the start of the TraceLog

member.name: T:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.ProcessIndex
member.summary:
Each process is given a unique index from 0 to TraceProcesses.Count-1 and unlike the OS Process ID, is unambiguous (The OS process ID can be reused after a process dies). ProcessIndex represents this index. By using an enum rather than an int it allows stronger typing and reduces the potential for errors.
It is expected that users of this library might keep arrays of size TraceProcesses.Count to store additional data associated with a process in the trace.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.ProcessIndex.Invalid
member.summary: Returned when no appropriate Process exists.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceProcesses
member.summary:
A TraceProcesses instance represents the list of processes in the Event log.
TraceProcesses are IEnumerable, and will return the processes in order of creation time.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceProcesses.Log
member.summary: The log associated with this collection of processes.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceProcesses.Count
member.summary: The count of the number of TraceProcess instances in the TraceProcesses list.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceProcesses.Item(Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.ProcessIndex)
member.summary: Each process that occurs in the log is given a unique index (which unlike the PID is unique), that ranges from 0 to Count - 1. Return the TraceProcess for the given index.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceProcesses.GetProcess(System.Int32,System.Double)
member.summary:
Given an OS process ID and a time, return the last TraceProcess that has the same process ID, and whose process start time is less than 'timeRelativeMSec'.
If 'timeRelativeMSec' is during the processes's lifetime this is guaranteed to be the correct process. for the given process ID since process IDs are unique during the lifetime of the process.
If timeRelativeMSec == TraceLog.SessionDuration this method will return the last process with the given process ID, even if it had died during the trace.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceProcesses.LastProcessWithID(System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns the last process in the log with the given process ID. Useful when the logging session was stopped just after the processes completed (a common scenario).

member.name: M:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceProcesses.FirstProcessWithName(System.String,System.Double)
member.summary:
Find the first process in the trace that has the process name 'processName' and whose process start time is after the given point in time.
A process's name is the file name of the EXE without the extension.
Processes that began before the trace started have a start time of 0, Thus specifying 0 for the time will include processes that began before the trace started.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceProcesses.LastProcessWithName(System.String,System.Double)
member.summary:
Find the last process in the trace that has the process name 'processName' and whose process start time is after the given point in time.
A process's name is the file name of the EXE without the extension.
Processes that began before the trace started have a start time of 0, Thus specifying 0 for the time will include processes that began before the trace started.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceProcesses.ToString
member.summary: An XML representation of the TraceEventProcesses (for debugging)

member.name: M:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceProcesses.System#Collections#Generic#IEnumerable{Microsoft#Diagnostics#Tracing#Etlx#TraceProcess}#GetEnumerator
member.summary: Enumerate all the processes that occurred in the trace log, ordered by creation time.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceProcesses.GetProcess(System.Int32,System.Int64)
member.summary: Given an OS process ID and a time, return the last TraceProcess that has the same process ID, and whose offset start time is less than 'timeQPC'. If 'timeQPC' is during the thread's lifetime this is guaranteed to be the correct process. Using timeQPC = TraceLog.sessionEndTimeQPC will return the last process with the given PID, even if it had died.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceProcesses.#ctor(Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceLog)
member.summary:
TraceProcesses represents the entire ETL moduleFile log. At the node level it is organized by threads.
The TraceProcesses also is where we put various caches that are independent of the process involved. These include a cache for TraceModuleFile that represent native images that can be loaded into a process, as well as the process lookup tables and a cache that remembers the last calls to GetNameForAddress().

member.name: T:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceProcess
member.summary: A TraceProcess represents a process in the trace.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceProcess.ProcessID
member.summary: The OS process ID associated with the process. It is NOT unique across the whole log. Use ProcessIndex for that.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceProcess.ProcessIndex
member.summary: The index into the logical array of TraceProcesses for this process. Unlike ProcessID (which may be reused after the process dies, the process index is unique in the log.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceProcess.Name
member.summary: This is a short name for the process. It is the image file name without the path or suffix.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceProcess.CommandLine
member.summary: The command line that started the process (may be empty string if unknown)

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceProcess.ImageFileName
member.summary: The path name of the EXE that started the process (may be empty string if unknown)

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceProcess.StartTime
member.summary: The time when the process started. Returns the time the trace started if the process existed when the trace started.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceProcess.StartTimeRelativeMsec
member.summary: The time when the process started. Returns the time the trace started if the process existed when the trace started. Returned as the number of MSec from the beginning of the trace.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceProcess.EndTime
member.summary: The time when the process ended. Returns the time the trace ended if the process existed when the trace ended. Returned as a DateTime

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceProcess.EndTimeRelativeMsec
member.summary: The time when the process ended. Returns the time the trace ended if the process existed when the trace ended. Returned as the number of MSec from the beginning of the trace.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceProcess.ParentID
member.summary: The process ID of the parent process

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceProcess.Parent
member.summary: The process that started this process. Returns null if unknown.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceProcess.ExitStatus
member.summary: If the process exited, the exit status of the process. Otherwise null.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceProcess.CPUMSec
member.summary: The amount of CPU time spent in this process based on the kernel CPU sampling events.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceProcess.Is64Bit
member.summary: Returns true if the process is a 64 bit process

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceProcess.Log
member.summary: The log file associated with the process.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceProcess.Threads
member.summary: A list of all the threads that occurred in this process.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceProcess.LoadedModules
member.summary: Returns the list of modules that were loaded by the process. The modules may be managed or native, and include native modules that were loaded event before the trace started.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceProcess.EventsInProcess
member.summary: Filters events to only those for a particular process.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceProcess.EventsDuringProcess
member.summary: Filters events to only that occurred during the time the process was alive.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceProcess.ToString
member.summary: An XML representation of the TraceEventProcess (for debugging)

member.name: M:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceProcess.#ctor(System.Int32,Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceLog,Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.ProcessIndex)
member.summary: Create a new TraceProcess. It should only be done by log.CreateTraceProcess because only TraceLog is responsible for generating a new ProcessIndex which we need. 'processIndex' is a index that is unique for the whole log file (where as processID can be reused).

member.name: F:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceProcess.codeAddressesInProcess
member.summary: This table allows us to intern codeAddress so we only at most one distinct address per process.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceProcess.unresolvedCodeAddresses
member.summary: We also keep track of those code addresses that are NOT yet resolved to at least a File (for JIT compiled things this would be to a method

member.name: T:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceProcess.MethodLookupInfo
member.summary: This is all the information needed to remember about at JIT compiled method (used in the jitMethods variable)

member.name: F:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceProcess.jitMethods
member.summary:
This table has a entry for each JIT compiled method that remembers its range. It is actually only needed for the real time case, as the non-real time case you resolve code addresses on method unload/rundown and thus don't need to remember the information. This table is NOT persisted in the ETLX file since is only needed to convert raw addresses into TraceMethods.
It is a array of arrays to make insertion efficient. Most of the time JIT methods will be added in contiguous memory (thus will be in order), however from time to time things will 'jump around' to a new segment. By having a list of lists, (which are in order in both lists) you can efficiently (log(N)) search as well as insert.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceProcess.scheduledActivityIdToActivityIndex
member.summary: Maps a newly scheduled "user" activity ID to the ActivityIndex of the Activity. This keeps track of currently created/scheduled activities that have not started yet, and for multi-trigger events, created/scheduled activities that have not conclusively "died" (e.g. by having their "user" activity ID reused by another activity).

member.name: T:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.ThreadIndex
member.summary:
Each thread is given a unique index from 0 to TraceThreads.Count-1 and unlike the OS Thread ID, is unambiguous (The OS thread ID can be reused after a thread dies). ThreadIndex represents this index. By using an enum rather than an int it allows stronger typing and reduces the potential for errors.
It is expected that users of this library might keep arrays of size TraceThreads.Count to store additional data associated with a process in the trace.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.ThreadIndex.Invalid
member.summary: Returned when no appropriate Thread exists.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceThreads
member.summary: A TraceThreads represents the list of threads in a process.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceThreads.System#Collections#Generic#IEnumerable{Microsoft#Diagnostics#Tracing#Etlx#TraceThread}#GetEnumerator
member.summary: Enumerate all the threads that occurred in the trace log. It does so in order of their thread offset events in the log.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceThreads.Count
member.summary: The count of the number of TraceThreads in the trace log.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceThreads.Item(Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.ThreadIndex)
member.summary: Each thread that occurs in the log is given a unique index (which unlike the PID is unique), that ranges from 0 to Count - 1. Return the TraceThread for the given index.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceThreads.GetThread(System.Int32,System.Double)
member.summary: Given an OS thread ID and a time, return the last TraceThread that has the same thread ID, and whose start time is less than 'timeRelativeMSec'. If 'timeRelativeMSec' is during the thread's lifetime this is guaranteed to be the correct thread.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceThreads.ToString
member.summary: An XML representation of the TraceThreads (for debugging)

member.name: M:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceThreads.#ctor(Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceLog)
member.summary: TraceThreads represents the collection of threads in a process.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceThreads.GetOrCreateThread(System.Int32,System.Int64,Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceProcess,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Get the thread for threadID and timeQPC. Create if necessary. If 'isThreadCreateEvent' is true, then force the creation of a new thread EVEN if the thread exist since we KNOW it is a new thread (and somehow we missed the threadEnd event). Process is the process associated with the thread. It can be null if you really don't know the process ID. We will try to fill it in on another event where we DO know the process id (ThreadEnd event).

member.name: T:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceThread
member.summary: A TraceThread represents a thread of execution in a process.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceThread.ThreadID
member.summary: The OS process ID associated with the process.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceThread.ThreadIndex
member.summary: The index into the logical array of TraceThreads for this process. Unlike ThreadId (which may be reused after the thread dies) the T index is unique over the log.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceThread.Process
member.summary: The process associated with the thread.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceThread.StartTime
member.summary: The time when the thread started. Returns the time the trace started if the thread existed when the trace started. Returned as a DateTime

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceThread.StartTimeRelativeMSec
member.summary: The time when the thread started. Returns the time the trace started if the thread existed when the trace started. Returned as the number of MSec from the beginning of the trace.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceThread.EndTime
member.summary: The time when the thread ended. Returns the time the trace ended if the thread existed when the trace ended. Returned as a DateTime

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceThread.EndTimeRelativeMSec
member.summary: The time when the thread ended. Returns the time the trace ended if the thread existed when the trace ended. Returned as the number of MSec from the beginning of the trace.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceThread.CPUMSec
member.summary: The amount of CPU time spent on this thread based on the kernel CPU sampling events.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceThread.EventsInThread
member.summary: Filters events to only those for a particular thread.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceThread.EventsDuringThread
member.summary: Filters events to only those that occurred during the time a the thread was alive.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceThread.GetActivityIndex(System.Double)
member.summary: REturns the activity this thread was working on at the time instant 'relativeMsec'

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceThread.DefaultActivityIndex
member.summary: Represents the "default" activity for the thread, the activity that no one has set

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceThread.ThreadInfo
member.summary: ThreadInfo is a string that identifies the thread symbolically. (e.g. .NET Threadpool, .NET GC) It may return null if there is no useful symbolic name.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceThread.VerboseThreadName
member.summary: VerboseThreadName is a name for the thread including the ThreadInfo and the CPU time used.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceThread.UserStackBase
member.summary: The base of the thread's stack. This is just past highest address in memory that is part of the stack (we don't really know the lower bound (userStackLimit is this lower bound at the time the thread was created which is not very useful).

member.name: M:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceThread.ToString
member.summary: An XML representation of the TraceThread (for debugging)

member.name: M:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceThread.#ctor(System.Int32,Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceProcess,Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.ThreadIndex)
member.summary: Create a new TraceProcess. It should only be done by log.CreateTraceProcess because only TraceLog is responsible for generating a new ProcessIndex which we need. 'processIndex' is a index that is unique for the whole log file (where as processID can be reused).

member.name: F:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceThread.activityIds
member.summary: This is a list of the activities (snippet of threads) that have run on this thread. They are ordered by time so you can binary search for your activity based on timestamp.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceThread.lastBlockingCSwitchEventIndex
member.summary: We want to have the stack for when CSwtichs BLOCK as well as when they unblock. this variable keeps track of the last blocking CSWITCH on this thread so that we can compute this. It is only used during generation of a TraceLog file.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceLoadedModules
member.summary: TraceLoadedModules represents the collection of modules (loaded DLLs or EXEs) in a particular process.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceLoadedModules.Process
member.summary: The process in which this Module is loaded.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceLoadedModules.GetModuleContainingAddress(System.UInt64,System.Double)
member.summary:
Returns the module which was mapped into memory at at 'timeRelativeMSec' and includes the address 'address'
Note that Jit compiled code is placed into memory that is not associated with the module and thus will not be found by this method.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceLoadedModules.GetLoadedModule(System.String,System.Double)
member.summary: Returns the module representing the unmanaged load of a particular fiele at a given time.

member.summary: An XML representation of the TraceLoadedModules (for debugging)

member.summary: Returns all modules in the process. Note that managed modules may appear twice (once for the managed load and once for an unmanaged (LoadLibrary) load.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceLoadedModules.GetLoadedModule(System.String,System.Int64)
member.summary: This function will find the module associated with 'address' at 'timeQPC' however it will only find modules that are mapped in memory (module associated with JIT compiled methods will not be found).

member.name: M:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceLoadedModules.FindManagedModuleAndIndex(System.Int64,System.Int64,System.Int32@)
member.summary: Finds the index and module for an a given managed module ID. If not found, new module should be inserted at index + 1;

member.name: M:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceLoadedModules.FindModuleAndIndexContainingAddress(System.UInt64,System.Int64,System.Int32@)
member.summary: Finds the index and module for an address that lives within the image. If the module did not match the new entry should go at index+1.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceLoadedModule
member.summary: A TraceLoadedModule represents a module (DLL or EXE) that was loaded into a process. It represents the time that this module was mapped into the processes address space.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceLoadedModule.ImageBase
member.summary: The address where the DLL or EXE was loaded. Will return 0 for managed modules without NGEN images.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceLoadedModule.LoadTime
member.summary: The load time is the time the LoadLibrary was done if it was loaded from a file, otherwise is the time the CLR loaded the module. Expressed as a DateTime

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceLoadedModule.LoadTimeRelativeMSec
member.summary: The load time is the time the LoadLibrary was done if it was loaded from a file, otherwise is the time the CLR loaded the module. Expressed as as MSec from the beginning of the trace.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceLoadedModule.UnloadTime
member.summary: The load time is the time the FreeLibrary was done if it was unmanaged, otherwise is the time the CLR unloaded the module. Expressed as a DateTime

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceLoadedModule.UnloadTimeRelativeMSec
member.summary: The load time is the time the FreeLibrary was done if it was unmanaged, otherwise is the time the CLR unloaded the module. Expressed as MSec from the beginning of the trace.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceLoadedModule.Process
member.summary: The process that loaded this module

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceLoadedModule.ModuleID
member.summary: An ID that uniquely identifies the module in within the process. Works for both the managed and unmanaged case.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceLoadedModule.ModuleFile
member.summary: If this managedModule was a file that was mapped into memory (eg LoadLibary), then ModuleFile points at it. If a managed module does not have a file associated with it, this can be null.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceLoadedModule.FilePath
member.summary: Shortcut for ModuleFile.FilePath, but returns the empty string if ModuleFile is null

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceLoadedModule.Name
member.summary: Shortcut for ModuleFile.Name, but returns the empty string if ModuleFile is null

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceLoadedModule.ManagedModule
member.summary:
Because .NET applications have AppDomains, a module that is loaded once from a process perspective, might be loaded several times (once for each AppDomain) from a .NET perspective
This property returns the loadedModule record for the first such managed module load associated with this load.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceManagedModule.ModuleID
member.summary: The module ID that the .NET Runtime uses to identify the file (module) associated with this managed module

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceManagedModule.AssmeblyID

member.name: T:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.CallStackIndex
member.summary: CallStackIndex uniquely identifies a callstack within the log. Valid values are between 0 and TraceCallStacks.Count-1. Thus, an array can be used to 'attach' data to a call stack.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.CallStackIndex.Invalid
member.summary: Returned when no appropriate CallStack exists.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceCallStacks
member.summary:
Call stacks are so common in most traces, that having a .NET object (a TraceEventCallStack) for each one is often too expensive. As optimization, TraceLog also assigns a call stack index to every call stack and this index uniquely identifies the call stack in a very light weight fashion.
To be useful, however you need to be able to ask questions about a call stack index without creating a TraceEventCallStack. This is the primary purpose of a TraceCallStacks (accessible from TraceLog.CallStacks). It has a set of methods that take a CallStackIndex and return properties of the call stack (like its caller or its code address).

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceCallStacks.Count
member.summary: Returns the count of call stack indexes (all Call Stack indexes are strictly less than this).

member.name: M:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceCallStacks.CodeAddressIndex(Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.CallStackIndex)
member.summary: Given a call stack index, return the code address index representing the top most frame associated with it

member.name: M:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceCallStacks.Caller(Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.CallStackIndex)
member.summary: Given a call stack index, look up the call stack index for caller. Returns CallStackIndex.Invalid at top of stack.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceCallStacks.Depth(Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.CallStackIndex)
member.summary: Given a call stack index, returns the number of callers for the call stack

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceCallStacks.Item(Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.CallStackIndex)
member.summary: Given a call stack index, returns a TraceCallStack for it.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceCallStacks.CodeAddresses
member.summary: Returns the TraceCodeAddresses instance that can resolve CodeAddressIndexes in the TraceLog

member.name: M:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceCallStacks.ThreadIndex(Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.CallStackIndex)
member.summary: Given a call stack index, returns the ThreadIndex which represents the thread for the call stack

member.name: M:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceCallStacks.Thread(Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.CallStackIndex)
member.summary: Given a call stack index, returns the TraceThread which represents the thread for the call stack

member.name: M:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceCallStacks.ToString
member.summary: An XML representation of the TraceCallStacks (used for debugging)

member.name: M:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceCallStacks.GetEnumerator
member.summary: IEnumerable Support

member.name: M:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceCallStacks.SetSize(System.Int32)
member.summary: Used to 'undo' the effects of adding a eventToStack that you no longer want. This happens when we find out that a eventToStack is actually got more callers in it (when a eventToStack is split).

member.name: M:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceCallStacks.GetRootForThread(Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.ThreadIndex)
member.summary: Returns an index that represents the 'threads' of the stack. It encodes the thread which owns this stack into this. We encode this as -ThreadIndex - 2 (since -1 is the Invalid node)

member.name: T:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceCallStack
member.summary: A TraceCallStack is a structure that represents a call stack as a linked list. Each TraceCallStack contains two properties, the CodeAddress for the current frame, and the TraceCallStack of the caller of this frame. The Caller property will return null at the thread start frame.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceCallStack.CallStackIndex
member.summary: Return the CallStackIndex that uniquely identifies this call stack in the TraceLog.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceCallStack.CodeAddress
member.summary: Returns the TraceCodeAddress for the current method frame in the linked list of frames.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceCallStack.Caller
member.summary: The TraceCallStack for the caller of of the method represented by this call stack. Returns null at the end of the list.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceCallStack.Depth
member.summary: The depth (count of callers) of this call stack.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceCallStack.ToString
member.summary: An XML representation of the TraceCallStack (used for debugging)

member.name: M:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceCallStack.ToString(System.Text.StringBuilder)
member.summary: Writes an XML representation of the TraceCallStack to the stringbuilder 'sb'

member.name: T:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.CodeAddressIndex
member.summary: CodeAddressIndex uniquely identifies a symbolic codeAddress within the log . Valid values are between 0 and TraceCodeAddresses.Count. Thus, an array can be used to 'attach' data to a code address.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.CodeAddressIndex.Invalid
member.summary: Returned when no appropriate Method exists.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceCodeAddresses
member.summary:
Code addresses are so common in most traces, that having a .NET object (a TraceCodeAddress) for each one is often too expensive. As optimization, TraceLog also assigns a code address index to every code address and this index uniquely identifies the code address in a very light weight fashion.
To be useful, however you need to be able to ask questions about a code address index without creating a TraceCodeAddress. This is the primary purpose of a TraceCodeAddresses (accessible from TraceLog.CodeAddresses). It has a set of methods that take a CodeAddressIndex and return properties of the code address (like its method, address, and module file)

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceCodeAddresses.Count
member.summary: Returns the count of code address indexes (all code address indexes are strictly less than this).

member.name: M:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceCodeAddresses.Name(Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.CodeAddressIndex)
member.summary: Given a code address index, return the name associated with it (the method name). It will have the form MODULE!METHODNAME. If the module name is unknown a ? is used, and if the method name is unknown a hexadecimal number is used as the method name.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceCodeAddresses.Address(Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.CodeAddressIndex)
member.summary: Given a code address index, returns the virtual address of the code in the process.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceCodeAddresses.ModuleFileIndex(Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.CodeAddressIndex)
member.summary: Given a code address index, returns the index for the module file (representing the file's path)

member.name: M:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceCodeAddresses.MethodIndex(Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.CodeAddressIndex)
member.summary: Given a code address index, returns the index for the method associated with the code address (it may return MethodIndex.Invalid if no method can be found).

member.name: M:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceCodeAddresses.ModuleFile(Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.CodeAddressIndex)
member.summary: Given a code address index, returns the module file (the DLL paths) associated with it

member.name: M:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceCodeAddresses.ILOffset(Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.CodeAddressIndex)
member.summary: If the code address is associated with managed code, return the IL offset within the method. If the method is unmanaged -1 is returned. To determine the IL offset the PDB for the NGEN image (for NGENed code) or the correct .NET events (for JIT compiled code) must be present. If this information is not present -1 is returned.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceCodeAddresses.Item(Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.CodeAddressIndex)
member.summary: Given a code address index, returns a TraceCodeAddress for it.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceCodeAddresses.Methods
member.summary: Returns the TraceMethods object that can look up information from MethodIndexes

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceCodeAddresses.ModuleFiles
member.summary: Returns the TraceModuleFiles that can look up information about ModuleFileIndexes

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceCodeAddresses.ManagedMethodRecordCount
member.summary: Indicates the number of managed method records that were encountered. This is useful to understand if symbolic information 'mostly works'.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceCodeAddresses.LookupSymbolsForModule(Microsoft.Diagnostics.Symbols.SymbolReader,Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceModuleFile)
member.summary: Initially CodeAddresses for unmanaged code will have no useful name. Calling LookupSymbolsForModule lets you resolve the symbols for a particular file so that the TraceCodeAddresses for that DLL will have Methods (useful names) associated with them.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceCodeAddresses.GetSourceLine(Microsoft.Diagnostics.Symbols.SymbolReader,Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.CodeAddressIndex)
member.summary:
A TraceCodeAddress can contain a method name, but does not contain number information. To find line number information you must read the PDB again and fetch it. This is what GetSoruceLine does.
Given a SymbolReader (which knows how to look up PDBs) and a code address index (which represent a particular point in execution), find a SourceLocation (which represents a particular line number in a particular source file associated with the code address. Returns null if anything goes wrong (and diagnostic information will be written to the log file associated with the SymbolReader.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceCodeAddresses.TotalCodeAddresses
member.summary:
The number of times a particular code address appears in the log. Unlike TraceCodeAddresses.Count, which tries to share a code address as much as possible, TotalCodeAddresses counts the same code address in different call stacks (and even if in the same stack) as distinct. This makes TotalCodeAddresses a better measure of the 'popularity' of a particular address (which can factor into decisions about whether to call LookupSymbolsForModule)
The sum of ModuleFile.CodeAddressesInModule for all modules should sum to this number.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceCodeAddresses.UnsafePDBMatching
member.summary: If set to true, will only use the name of the module and not the PDB GUID to confirm that a PDB is correct for a given DLL. Setting this value is dangerous because it is easy for the PDB to be for a different version of the DLL and thus give inaccurate method names. Nevertheless, if a log file has no PDB GUID information associated with it, unsafe PDB matching is the only way to get at least some symbolic information.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceCodeAddresses.ToString
member.summary: Returns an XML representation of the TraceCodeAddresses (for debugging)

member.name: M:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceCodeAddresses.NativeMap(Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.CodeAddressIndex)
member.summary: We expose ILToNativeMap internally so we can do diagnostics.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceCodeAddresses.GetEnumerator
member.summary: IEnumerable support.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceCodeAddresses.OpenPdbForModuleFileWithCache(Microsoft.Diagnostics.Symbols.SymbolReader,Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceModuleFile)
member.summary: Calls OpenPdbForModuleFile and caches the last entry

member.name: M:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceCodeAddresses.AddMethod(Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Parsers.Clr.MethodLoadUnloadVerboseTraceData)
member.summary: Called when JIT CLR Rundown events are processed. It will look if there is any address that falls into the range of the JIT compiled method and if so log the symbolic information (otherwise we simply ignore it)

member.name: M:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceCodeAddresses.AddMethod(Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Parsers.JScript.MethodLoadUnloadJSTraceData,System.Collections.Generic.Dictionary{Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.JavaScriptSourceKey,System.String})
member.summary: Adds a JScript method

member.name: M:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceCodeAddresses.ForAllUnresolvedCodeAddressesInRange(Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceProcess,System.UInt64,System.Int32,Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceCodeAddresses.ForAllCodeAddrAction)
member.summary: Allows you to get a callback for each code address that is in the range from start to start+length within the process 'process'.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceCodeAddresses.GetOrCreateCodeAddressIndex(Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceProcess,System.UInt64)
member.summary: Gets the symbolic information entry for 'address' which can be any address. If it falls in the range of a symbol, then that symbolic information is returned. Regardless of whether symbolic information is found, however, an entry is created for it, so every unique address has an entry in this table.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceCodeAddresses.ProcessForAddress(Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceProcess,System.UInt64)
member.summary: All processes might have kernel addresses in them, this returns the kernel process (process ID == 0) if 'address' is a kernel address.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceCodeAddresses.GetSortedCodeAddressIndexes
member.summary: Sort from lowest address to highest address.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceCodeAddresses.LookupSymbols(Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceLogOptions)
member.summary: Do symbol resolution for all addresses in the log file.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceCodeAddresses.OpenPdbForModuleFile(Microsoft.Diagnostics.Symbols.SymbolReader,Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceModuleFile)
member.summary: Look up the SymbolModule (open PDB) for a given moduleFile. Will generate NGEN pdbs as needed.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceCodeAddresses.CodeAddressInfo
member.summary:
A CodeAddressInfo is the actual data stored in the ETLX file that represents a TraceCodeAddress. It knows its Address in the process and it knows the TraceModuleFile (which knows its base address), so it also knows its relative address in the TraceModuleFile (which is what is needed to look up the value in the PDB.
Note that by the time that the CodeAddressInfo is persisted in the ETLX file it no longer knows the process it originated from (thus separate processes with the same address and same DLL file loaded at the same address can share the same CodeAddressInfo. This is actually reasonably common, since OS tend to load at their preferred base address.
We also have to handle the managed case, in which case the CodeAddressInfo may also know about the TraceMethod or the ILMapIndex (which remembers both the method and the line numbers for managed code.
However when the CodeAddressInfo is first created, we don't know the TraceModuleFile so we also need to remember the Process

member.name: M:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceCodeAddresses.CodeAddressInfo.GetProcessIndex(Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceCodeAddresses)
member.summary: This is only valid until MethodIndex or ModuleFileIndex is set.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceCodeAddresses.CodeAddressInfo.GetMethodIndex(Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceCodeAddresses)
member.summary: Only for managed code.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceCodeAddresses.FindAndRemove(System.Int64,Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.ProcessIndex,Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceCodeAddresses.ILMapIndex@)

member.name: T:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceCodeAddress
member.summary:
Conceptually a TraceCodeAddress represents a particular point of execution within a particular line of code in some source code. As a practical matter, they are represented two ways depending on whether the code is managed or not.
* For native code (or NGened code), it is represented as a virtual addresis along with the loaded native module that includes that address along with its load address. A code address does NOT know its process because they can be shared among all processes that load a particular module at a particular location. These code addresses will not have methods associated with them unless symbols information (PDBS) are loaded for the module using the LookupSymbolsForModule.
* For JIT compiled managed code, the address in a process is eagerly resolved into a method, module and an IL offset and that is stored in the TraceCodeAddress.
Sometimes it is impossible to even determine the module associated with a virtual address in a process. These are represented as simply the virtual address.
Because code addresses are so numerous, consider using CodeAddressIndex instead of TraceCodeAddress to represent a code address. Methods on TraceLog.CodeAddresses can access all the information that would be in a TraceCodeAddress from a CodeAddressIndex without the overhead of creating a TraceCodeAddress object.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceCodeAddress.CodeAddressIndex
member.summary: The CodeAddressIndex that uniquely identifies the same code address as this TraceCodeAddress

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceCodeAddress.Address
member.summary: The Virtual address of the code address in the process. (Note that the process is unknown by the code address to allow for sharing)

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceCodeAddress.FullMethodName
member.summary: The full name (Namespace name.class name.method name) of the method associated with this code address. Returns the empty string if no method is associated with the code address.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceCodeAddress.Method
member.summary: Returns the TraceMethod associated with this code address or null if there is none.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceCodeAddress.ILOffset
member.summary: If the TraceCodeAddress is associated with managed code, return the IL offset within the method. If the method is unmanaged -1 is returned. To determine the IL offset the PDB for the NGEN image (for NGENed code) or the correct .NET events (for JIT compiled code) must be present. If this information is not present -1 is returned.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceCodeAddress.GetSourceLine(Microsoft.Diagnostics.Symbols.SymbolReader)
member.summary:
A TraceCodeAddress can contain a method name, but does not contain number information. To find line number information you must read the PDB again and fetch it. This is what GetSoruceLine does.
Given a SymbolReader (which knows how to look up PDBs) find a SourceLocation (which represents a particular line number in a particular source file associated with the current TraceCodeAddress. Returns null if anything goes wrong (and diagnostic information will be written to the log file associated with the SymbolReader.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.MethodIndex
member.summary: MethodIndex uniquely identifies a method within the log. Valid values are between 0 and TraceMethods.Count-1. Thus, an array can be used to 'attach' data to a method.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.MethodIndex.Invalid
member.summary: Returned when no appropriate Method exists.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceMethods
member.summary:
Methods are so common in most traces, that having a .NET object (a TraceMethod) for each one is often too expensive. As optimization, TraceLog also assigns a method index to every method and this index uniquely identifies the method in a very light weight fashion.
To be useful, however you need to be able to ask questions about a method index without creating a TraceMethod. This is the primary purpose of a TraceMethods (accessible from TraceLog.CodeAddresses.Methods). It has a set of methods that take a MethodIndex and return properties of the method (like its name, and module file)

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceMethods.Count
member.summary: Returns the count of method indexes. All MethodIndexes are strictly less than this.

member.summary: The TraceModuleFile represents a executable file that can be loaded into memory (either an EXE or a DLL). It represents the path on disk as well as the location in memory where it loads (or its ModuleID if it is a managed module), but not the load or unload time or the process in which it was loaded (this allows them to be shared within the trace).

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceModuleFile.CodeAddressesInModule
member.summary:
The number of code addresses included in this module. This is useful for determining if this module is worth having its symbolic information looked up or not. It is not otherwise a particularly interesting metric.
This number is defined as the number of appearances this module has in any stack or any event with a code address (If the modules appears 5 times in a stack that counts as 5 even though it is just one event's stack).

member.name: T:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceActivity
member.summary:
Representation of an Activity. An activity can be thought of as a unit of execution associated with a task or workitem; it executes on one thread, and has a start and end time. An activity keeps track of its "creator" or "caller" -- which is the activity that scheduled it. Using the "creator" link a user can determine the chain of activities that led up to the current one.
Given an event you can get the Activity for the event using the Activity() extension method.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceLogOptions
member.summary: TraceLogOptions control the generation of a TraceLog (ETLX file) from an ETL file.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceLogOptions.#ctor
member.summary: Creates a new object containing options for constructing a TraceLog file.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceLogOptions.ShouldResolveSymbols
member.summary: If non-null, this is a predicate that, given a file path to a dll, answers the question whether the PDB associated with that DLL be looked up and its symbolic information added to the TraceLog file as part of conversion. Symbols can be looked up afterward when the file is later opened, so the default (which is to look up no symbols during conversion) is typically OK.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceLogOptions.LocalSymbolsOnly
member.summary: Resolving symbols from a symbol server can take a long time. If there is a DLL that always fails, it can be quite annoying because it will always cause delays, By specifying only local symbols it will only resolve the symbols if it can do so without the delay of network traffic. Symbols that have been previously cached locally from a symbol server count as local symbols.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceLogOptions.AlwaysResolveSymbols
member.summary: By default symbols are only resolved if there are stacks associated with the trace. Setting this option forces resolution even if there are no stacks.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceLogOptions.ConversionLog
member.summary: Writes status to this log. Useful for debugging symbol issues.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceLogOptions.ConversionLogName
member.summary: If ConversionLogName is set, it indicates that any messages associated with creating the TraceLog should be written here.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceLogOptions.KeepAllEvents
member.summary:
ETL files typically contain a large number of 'bookkeeping' event for resolving names of files, or methods or to indicate information about processes that existed when the trace was started (DCStart and DCStop events). By default these events are stripped from the ETLX file because their information has already been used to do the bookkeeping as part of the conversion
However sometimes it is useful to keep these events (typically for debugging TraceEvent itself) and setting this property to true will cause every event in the ETL file to be copied as an event to the ETLX file.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceLogOptions.MaxEventCount
member.summary:
Sometimes ETL files are too big , and you just want to look at a fraction of it to speed things up (or to keep file size under control). The MaxEventCount property allows that. 10M will produce a 3-4GB ETLX file. 1M is a good value to keep ETLX file size under control. Note that that the conversion still scan the entire original ETL file too look for bookkeeping events, however MaxEventCount events will be transfered to the ETLX file as events.
The default is 10M because ETLX has a restriction of 4GB in size.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceLogOptions.SkipMSec
member.summary: If an ETL file has too many events for efficient processing the first part of the trace can be skipped by setting this property. Any event which happens before 'SkipMSec' into the session will be filtered out. This property is intended to be used along with the MaxEventCount property to carve out a arbitrary chunk of time from an ETL file as it is converted to an ETLX file.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceLogOptions.OnLostEvents
member.summary: If this delegate is non-null, it is called if there are any lost events or if the file was truncated. It is passed a bool whether the ETLX file was truncated, as well as the number of lost events and the total number of events in the ETLX file. You can throw if you want to abort.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceLogOptions.ExplicitManifestDir
member.summary: If you have the manifests for particular providers, you can read them in explicitly by setting this directory. All files of the form *.manifest.xml will be read into the DynamicTraceEventParser's database before conversion starts.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Tracing.Etlx.TraceLogExtensions
